Some pivotal moments arrive wrapped as heartbreak‚Äîand end up becoming the reset you didn't know you needed. üíî 

Years ago, I was preparing to make a major life move. I had resigned from my job (even turning down a promotion), packed up my apartment, and was ready to relocate across the country for a relationship. 

A week before I was supposed to move, my then-boyfriend showed up at my empty apartment and ended things.

In that moment, I had two choices:
1) Call my boss and ask for my job back.
2) Step back, reevaluate everything, and choose a different path forward. 

I'd worked since I was 12 years old, and I was about to turn 30. So, I decided to take a little time off. I bought a one-way ticket, traveled for six months, and finally gave myself the space to figure out what I actually wanted‚Äîfrom my career and from my life.

When I came back, I was more focused and determined than ever. I took a big role at IAC, which ultimately put me on the path to becoming Revlon‚Äôs international CFO five years later.

That moment changed everything for me. In addition to making me rethink what I wanted from my career, it also forced me to reflect on what I needed in a partner‚Äîsomeone who would support my ambitions. 

That's exactly what I found. My husband is my biggest cheerleader, the best decision I've ever made, and I wouldn't be here without his unwavering support.

Pivotal moments rarely feel inspirational while you're living them. More often, they feel like everything is falling apart but sometimes they‚Äôre clearing the path for what comes next.

It's been equal parts exciting, emotional, and surreal to watch him begin this next chapter. Walking these campuses, I can't help but think back to my own college journey and how far our family has come.

I was the first in my family to go to college and I took that responsibility seriously. I started working at the age of 12, first as a babysitter, and then as a hostess and server to put myself through college.

Picking what to study was an entirely pragmatic decision. I wanted stability and to make sure I could take care of myself without ever having to rely on anyone else.

So, I studied accounting at the State University of New York at Albany. State University was my only option, and I chose Albany because it had an incredible business school. I knew people always needed accountants, even in a recession. That decision changed the course of my life.

Watching my son now explore his options touches me deeply. It reminds me that every generation stands on the shoulders of the one before. My parents worked tirelessly so that I could open new doors, and now, I get to watch my son walk through doors that didn't exist for me. 

As a mom, I see my son‚Äôs future. As a leader, I see the bigger picture: this generation will step into a world that‚Äôs evolving faster than ever. The choices they make‚Äîabout curiosity, courage, and connection‚Äîwill shape not just their lives but the way we all work and live.

Over time, I‚Äôve learned that wellbeing isn‚Äôt a single action, but a rhythm you build. It takes consistency, intention, and a willingness to prioritize yourself‚Äîeven on the busiest days. Ultimately, you must put your own oxygen mask on before helping someone else with theirs. 

Here are a few wellness practices that have made a difference for me:

- Move every day. I aim for some form of daily exercise or movement. I also get my steps in (at least 10,000) even if it means walking between meetings or during calls, or getting on the treadmill at the end of a long day.  

- Keep it simple. The power of a routine lies in its repeatability‚Äîit eliminates unnecessary decision-making around simple tasks. For example, I eat the same lunch most days.

- Make time for recovery. I used to think performance came from pushing harder. I‚Äôve learned it comes just as much from sleep, rest, and letting your body and mind recharge. 

- Stay connected. Community is a powerful anchor. For me, family, friends, and colleagues remind me what really matters. I carve out time for them and I stick to my commitments. 

- Lead by example. True wellbeing doesn't stop with the individual, it thrives when it becomes part of a company's culture. In my experience, when leaders prioritize it openly, others feel permission to do the same.

One of my most meaningful moments recently was when a colleague texted me to say my focus on wellness inspired them to start their own fitness journey. They felt healthier and more energized as a result. That impact goes far beyond the gym‚Äîit‚Äôs about building a culture at ServiceNow where we support each other to be at our best.

One of the most important lessons I've learned over the course of my career: don't make career moves to escape something uncomfortable, make them to run towards growth.

It's a subtle mindset shift, but it completely changes how you make decisions. 

So many career moves are driven by frustration‚Äî"I don't like my boss," "I don't like the work." The grass always looks greener somewhere else.

That mindset causes people to run AWAY from what's uncomfortable instead of being clear about what they're actually running toward. 

The better filter is internal, not external. Asking yourself questions like: What am I learning here? What skills am I building? Where am I stretching in ways that will matter five or ten years from now?

Early in my career, I watched a lot of peers leave roles because the next job paid a little more or sounded better on paper. In that moment, it felt like progress but over time, many of those moves capped growth instead of accelerating it. 

To be clear, I'm not talking about cases where there are serious issues‚Äîthose are exceptions. Outside of that, the best career moves are intentional ones: running TOWARD opportunities that help you learn, grow, and build capabilities that matter long term.

There's one piece of counterintuitive advice that I often share: don't go for the "top job" before you're ready. 

I'm all for risk-taking and going after your goals, but I think it's also important to be humble and honest. Sometimes, it's about asking yourself: Where are the gaps in my skillset? What do I need to do to close them? 

Sometimes the best career move is taking the time to grow into the role you want, so you‚Äôre truly ready when the opportunity comes.

When I joined Ingram Micro, for example, the role was positioned as a CFO succession plan where I started as their EVP of Finance. Three years later, I was promoted to CFO.

At the time, of course, I was eager to move faster. In hindsight, that time was a gift. The opportunity to learn before leading was a game-changer because the scale and risk profile at Ingram was unlike anything I had managed before.

It gave me the skills and perspective not only to succeed as CFO at Ingram, but also to be fully prepared when the opportunity at ServiceNow came along.

The lesson I share often: Fill your toolbox before you grab the title. The right skills at the right time are what make the "top job" sustainable (and successful).
